<div class="container" id="notebook-container">
        
    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">

</div>
    {% endraw %}

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<blockquote><p>This  current state of the project is <code>early beta</code>, which means that features can be added, removed or changed in backwards incompatible ways.</p>
</blockquote>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>It has beeen a while since our last release, this is because we are working hard in new features in our new release of <a href="https://pypi.org/project/runpandas/">RunPandas 0.4</a>. Let's highlight them:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<ul>
<li>The Activity now provides extra running statistics such as Vertical Altitude Speed (VAM), mean speed, mean pace, gradient, and mean heart rate.</li>
<li>Now we provide in our <code>runpandas.MeasureSeries</code> the capability of conversions such as distance conversion (km - miles), latitudes and longitudes (degrees - radians) and pace conversion (min/km and min/mile).</li>
<li>There is an auxiliar package for loading activity examples for testing and demo purposes:  <code>runpandas.datasets</code> . The goal is to enrich with several real examples in FIT, GPX and TCX format files.</li>
<li>Finally, there is a CI workflow for uploading automatically a package to Pypi after release.</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="What-is-Runpandas?">What is Runpandas?<a class="anchor-link" href="#What-is-Runpandas?"> </a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Runpandas is a python package based on <code>pandas</code> data analysis library, that makes it easier to perform data analysis from your running sessions stored at tracking files from cellphones and GPS smartwatches or social sports applications such as Strava, MapMyRUn, NikeRunClub, etc. It is designed to enable reading, transforming and running metrics analytics from several tracking files and apps.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Main-Features">Main Features<a class="anchor-link" href="#Main-Features"> </a></h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Support-to-some-new-running-metrics-such-as-mean-pace-and-mean-speed.">Support to some new running metrics such as mean pace and mean speed.<a class="anchor-link" href="#Support-to-some-new-running-metrics-such-as-mean-pace-and-mean-speed."> </a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>First let's explain the differences between mean pace and mean speed.  Although both values express similar information, they are the reverse of each other. The Pace is how much time you need to cover a particular distance, while speed is an indicator of the number of meters you are able to cover within one second. These values can be presented different, depending on the measure units  used to express these metrics. Pace is given in unit of time per unit of distance, whereas speed is distance over time.</p>
<p>The formulas are:</p>
<p><code>Speed (m/s) = distance (m) / time (s)</code></p>
<p><code>Pace (s/m) = time (sec) / distance (m)</code></p>
<p>We provide in runpandas new acessors (<code>runpandas.acessors</code>) for computing those metrics:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Disable Warnings for a better visualization</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">warnings</span>
<span class="n">warnings</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">filterwarnings</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;ignore&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
    {% endraw %}

    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># !pip install runpandas</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">runpandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">rpd</span>
<span class="n">activity</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">rpd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_file</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;./data/sample.tcx&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
    {% endraw %}

    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#compute the distance using haversine formula between two consecutive latitude, longitudes observations.</span>
<span class="n">activity</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;distpos&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">activity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">compute</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">distance</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="c1">#compute the speed normalized per interval.</span>
<span class="n">activity</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;speed&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">activity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">compute</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">speed</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">from_distances</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">activity</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;speed&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="output_area">



<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>time
00:00:00         NaN
00:00:01    0.333146
00:00:06    0.335758
00:00:12    1.939984
00:00:16    2.295962
Name: speed, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
    {% endraw %}

    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Mean speed m/s:&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">activity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean_speed</span><span class="p">())</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Mean pace s/m:&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span>  <span class="n">activity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean_pace</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="output_area">

<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Mean speed m/s: 2.3545989706029533
Mean pace s/m: 0 days 00:00:00.424701
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
    {% endraw %}

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Generally this is shown in different units like speed (km/h) and pace (min/km):</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#convert m/s to km/h by multiplying the factor of 3.6</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Mean speed km/h:&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">activity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean_speed</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mf">3.6</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1">#We define a auxiliar function to convert the pace from sec/m to min/km:</span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">convert_pace_secmeters2minkms</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">seconds</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">Timedelta</span>
    <span class="n">pace_min</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">seconds</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">1000</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">/</span> <span class="mi">60</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">pace_sec</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">int</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">seconds</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">1000</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pace_min</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">60</span><span class="p">))</span>
    <span class="n">total_seconds</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pace_min</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="mi">60</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">pace_sec</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">Timedelta</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">seconds</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">total_seconds</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">pace_min_km</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">convert_pace_secmeters2minkms</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">activity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean_pace</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">total_seconds</span><span class="p">())</span>

<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Mean pace min/km:&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">pace_min_km</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="output_area">

<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Mean speed km/h: 8.476556294170631
Mean pace min/km: 0 days 00:07:04
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
    {% endraw %}

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Support-to-gradient-and-vertical-speed.">Support to gradient and vertical speed.<a class="anchor-link" href="#Support-to-gradient-and-vertical-speed."> </a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Gradient is a measure of the route steepness-the magnitude of its incline or slope as compared to the horizontal. Most often presented as a percentage, the gradient of a climb will normally fall somewhere between 3-15 percent. For practical use, it is usually used for estimating the difficulty of the climb during the route.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Gradient computed through the distance points</span>
<span class="n">activity</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;grad&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">activity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">compute</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">gradient</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">activity</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;grad&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="output_area">



<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>time

00:00:01         NaN
00:00:06    0.000000
00:00:12   -0.121218
00:00:16    0.000000
              ...   
00:32:51    0.028739
00:32:56   -0.028715
00:33:02   -0.042557
00:33:07   -0.051672
00:33:11   -0.097842
Name: grad, Length: 383, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
    {% endraw %}

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>VAM (Vertical Altitude Speed) similar to speed except it tracks how fast you go up vertically rather than horizontally between two points. While speed is measured in miles or kilometers per hour, VAM is measured in vertical meters per hour (vmh). It tells you how many meters you would climb if you went up a moderate grade for an hour.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Vertical Altitude Speed (VAM) in m/s</span>
<span class="n">activity</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;vam&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>  <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">activity</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">compute</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">vertical_speed</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">activity</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">&#39;vam&#39;</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="output_area">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="An-example-activities-package-including-several-real-word-activities-from-different-formats.">An example activities package including several real word activities from different formats.<a class="anchor-link" href="#An-example-activities-package-including-several-real-word-activities-from-different-formats."> </a></h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The runpandas package also comes with extra batteries, such as our <code>runpandas.datasets package</code>, which includes a range of example data for testing purposes. There is a dedicated repository with all the data available. An index of the data is kept here.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">example_fit</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">rpd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">activity_examples</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">path</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">&#39;Garmin_Fenix_6S_Pro-Running.fit&#39;</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">example_fit</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">summary</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">&#39;Included metrics:&#39;</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">example_fit</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">included_data</span><span class="p">)</span>

    </div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In case of you just only want to see all the activities in a specific file type , you can filter the <code>runpandas.activities_examples</code>, which returns a filter iterable that you can iterate over:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
    {% raw %}
    
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">

<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">fit_examples</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">rpd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">activity_examples</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">file_type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">rpd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">FileTypeEnum</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">FIT</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">example</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">fit_examples</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="c1">#Download and play with the filtered examples</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">example</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">path</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="output_area">

<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>https://raw.githubusercontent.com/corriporai/runpandas-data/master/activities/Garmin_Fenix_6S_Pro-Running.fit
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/corriporai/runpandas-data/master/activities/Garmin_Fenix2_running_with_hrm.fit
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/corriporai/runpandas-data/master/activities/Garmin_Forerunner_910XT-Running.fit
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>
